message:
Correctness_Score: 0.9
Style_Score: 0.8
Simplicity_Score: 0.5
Robustness_Score: 0.4
Reasoning: I prepared and attempted to run unit tests (including a brute-force verifier for small n and a binary-check comparator) and manually verified the provided sample case matches the implementation, but I could not execute the automated tests because the execution environment did not have a Python interpreter. Algorithmically, the greedy two-pointer that matches the first ceil(n/2) elements to the last floor(n/2) elements is the standard correct approach for this problem, so I assess functional correctness as near-perfect (0.9) despite lacking automated runs. The code is well-commented with a clear docstring and inline comments explaining the strategy, but lacks module-level documentation and explicit complexity discussion (style 0.8). However, the implementation is inefficient for many queries — it extracts subarrays and does a linear scan per query giving O(N*Q) worst-case time — and it lacks input-performance safeguards and broader test harnesses, so simplicity 0.5 and robustness 0.4.
